annotations.1: [1-18] The prologue states the main themes of the gospel: life, light, truth, the world, testimony, and the preexistence of Jesus Christ, the incarnate Logos, who reveals God the Father. In origin, it was probably an early Christian hymn. Its closest parallel is in other christological hymns, Col 1:15-20 and Philippians 2:6-11. Its core ( John 1:1-5, 10-11, 14) is poetic in structure, with short phrases linked by "staircase parallelism," in which the last word of one phrase becomes the first word of the next. Prose inserts (at least John 1:6-8, 15) deal with John the Baptist
annotations.2: [1] In the beginning: also the first words of the Old Testament ( Genesis 1:1). Was: this verb is used three times with different meanings in this verse: existence, relationship, and predication. The Word (Greek logos): this term combines God's dynamic, creative word (Genesis), personified preexistent Wisdom as the instrument of God's creative activity (Proverbs), and the ultimate intelligibility of reality (Hellenistic philosophy). With God: the Greek preposition here connotes communication with another. Was God: lack of a definite article with "God" in Greek signifies predication rather than identification.
annotations.3: [1] What came to be: while the oldest manuscripts have no punctuation here, the corrector of Bodmer Papyrus P75, some manuscripts, and the Ante-Nicene Fathers take this phrase with what follows, as staircase parallelism. Connection with John 1:3 reflects fourth-century anti-Arianism
annotations.4: [5] The ethical dualism of light and darkness is paralleled in intertestamental literature and in the Dead Sea Scrolls. Overcome: "comprehend" is another possible translation, but cf John 12:35; Wisdom 7:29-30
annotations.5: [6] John was sent just as Jesus was "sent" ( John 4:34) in divine mission. Other references to John the Baptist in this gospel emphasize the differences between them and John's subordinate role
annotations.6: [7] Testimony: the testimony theme of John is introduced, which portrays Jesus as if on trial throughout his ministry. All testify to Jesus: John the Baptist, the Samaritan woman, scripture, his works, the crowds, the Spirit, and his disciples
annotations.7: [11] What was his own . . . his own people: first a neuter, literally, "his own property/possession" (probably = Israel), then a masculine, "his own people" (the Israelites)
annotations.8: [13] Believers in Jesus become children of God not through any of the three natural causes mentioned but through God who is the immediate cause of the new spiritual life. Were born: the Greek verb can mean "begotten" (by a male) or "born" (from a female or of parents). The variant "he who was begotten," asserting Jesus' virginal conception, is weakly attested in Old Latin and Syriac versions
annotations.9: [14] Flesh: the whole person, used probably against docetic tendencies (cf 1 John 4:2; 1:7). Made his dwelling: literally, "pitched his tent/tabernacle." Cf the tabernacle or tent of meeting that was the place of God's presence among his people ( Exodus 25:8-9). The incarnate Word is the new mode of God's presence among his people. The Greek verb has the same consonants as the Aramaic word for God's presence (Shekinah). Glory: God's visible manifestation of majesty in power, which once filled the tabernacle ( Exodus 40:34) and the temple ( 1 Kings 8:10-11, 27), is now centered in Jesus. Only Son: Greek, monogenes, but see the note on John 1:18. Grace and truth: these words may represent two Old Testament terms describing Yahweh in covenant relationship with Israel (cf Exodus 34:6), thus God's "love" and "fidelity." The Word shares Yahweh's covenant qualities
annotations.10: [15] This verse, interrupting John 1:14, 16 seems drawn from John 1:30
annotations.11: [16] Grace in place of grace: replacement of the Old Covenant with the New (cf John 1:17). Other possible translations are "grace upon grace" (accumulation) and "grace for grace" (correspondence)
annotations.12: [18] The only Son, God: while the vast majority of later textual witnesses have another reading, "the Son, the only one" or "the only Son," the translation above follows the best and earliest manuscripts, monogenes theos, but takes the first term to mean not just "Only One" but to include a filial relationship with the Father, as at Luke 9:38 ("only child") or Hebrews 11:17 ("only son") and as translated at John 1:14. The Logos is thus "only Son" and God but not Father/God
annotations.13: [19-51] The testimony of John the Baptist about the Messiah and Jesus' self-revelation to the first disciples. This section constitutes the introduction to the gospel proper and is connected with the prose inserts in the prologue. It develops the major theme of testimony in four scenes: John's negative testimony about himself; his positive testimony about Jesus; the revelation of Jesus to Andrew and Peter; the revelation of Jesus to Philip and Nathanael
annotations.14: [19] The Jews: throughout most of the gospel, the "Jews" does not refer to the Jewish people as such but to the hostile authorities, both Pharisees and Sadducees, particularly in Jerusalem, who refuse to believe in Jesus. The usage reflects the atmosphere, at the end of the first century, of polemics between church and synagogue, or possibly it refers to Jews as representative of a hostile world ( John 1:10-11)
annotations.15: [20] Messiah: the anointed agent of Yahweh, usually considered to be of Davidic descent. See further the note on John 1:41
annotations.16: [21] Elijah: the Baptist did not claim to be Elijah returned to earth (cf Malachi 3:23; Matthew 11:14). The Prophet: probably the prophet like Moses ( Deut 18:15; cf Acts 3:22)
annotations.17: [23] This is a repunctuation and reinterpretation (as in the synoptic gospels and Septuagint) of the Hebrew text of Isaiah 40:3 which reads, "A voice cries out: In the desert prepare the way of the Lord."
annotations.18: [24] Some Pharisees: other translations, such as "Now they had been sent from the Pharisees," misunderstand the grammatical construction. This is a different group from that in John 1:19; the priests and Levites would have been Sadducees, not Pharisees
annotations.19: [26] I baptize with water: the synoptics add "but he will baptize you with the holy Spirit" ( Mark 1:8) or ". . . holy Spirit and fire" ( Matthew 3:11; Luke 3:16). John's emphasis is on purification and preparation for a better baptism
annotations.20: [28] Bethany across the Jordan: site unknown. Another reading is "Bethabara."
annotations.21: [29] The Lamb of God: the background for this title may be the victorious apocalyptic lamb who would destroy evil in the world (Rev 5-7; 17:14); the paschal lamb, whose blood saved Israel (Exodus 12); and/or the suffering servant led like a lamb to the slaughter as a sin-offering ( Isaiah 53:7, 10)
annotations.22: [30] He existed before me: possibly as Elijah (to come, John 1:27); for the evangelist and his audience, Jesus' preexistence would be implied (see the note on John 1:1)
annotations.23: [31] I did not know him: this gospel shows no knowledge of the tradition (Luke 1) about the kinship of Jesus and John the Baptist. The reason why I came baptizing with water: in this gospel, John's baptism is not connected with forgiveness of sins; its purpose is revelatory, that Jesus may be made known to Israel
annotations.24: [32] Like a dove: a symbol of the new creation ( Genesis 8:8) or the community of Israel ( Hosea 11:11). Remain: the first use of a favorite verb in John, emphasizing the permanency of the relationship between Father and Son (as here) and between the Son and the Christian. Jesus is the permanent bearer of the Spirit
annotations.25: [34] The Son of God: this reading is supported by good Greek manuscripts, including the Chester Beatty and Bodmer Papyri and the Vatican Codex, but is suspect because it harmonizes this passage with the synoptic version: "This is my beloved Son" ( Matthew 3:17; Mark 1:11; Luke 3:22). The poorly attested alternate reading, "God's chosen One," is probably a reference to the Servant of Yahweh ( Isaiah 42:1)
annotations.26: [36] John the Baptist's testimony makes his disciples' following of Jesus plausible
annotations.27: [37] The two disciples: Andrew ( John 1:40) and, traditionally, John, son of Zebedee (see the note on John 13:23)
annotations.28: [39] Four in the afternoon: literally, the tenth hour, from sunrise, in the Roman calculation of time. Some suggest that the next day, beginning at sunset, was the sabbath; they would have stayed with Jesus to avoid travel on it
annotations.29: [41] Messiah: the Hebrew word masiah, "anointed one" (see the note on Luke 2:11), appears in Greek as the transliterated messias only here and in John 4:25. Elsewhere the Greek translation christos is used
annotations.30: [42] Simon, the son of John: in Matthew 16:17, Simon is called Bariona, "son of Jonah," a different tradition for the name of Simon's father. Kephas: in Aramaic = the Rock; cf Matthew 16:18. Neither the Greek equivalent Petros nor, with one isolated exception, Kephas is attested as a personal name before Christian times
annotations.31: [43] He: grammatically, could be Peter, but logically is probably Jesus
annotations.32: [47] A true Israelite. There is no duplicity in him: Jacob was the first to bear the name "Israel" ( Genesis 32:29), but Jacob was a man of duplicity ( Genesis 27:35-36)
annotations.33: [48] Under the fig tree: a symbol of messianic peace (cf Micah 4:4; Zechariah 3:10)
annotations.34: [49] Son of God: this title is used in the Old Testament, among other ways, as a title of adoption for the Davidic king ( 2 Sam 7:14; Psalm 2:7; 89:27), and thus here, with King of Israel, in a messianic sense. For the evangelist, Son of God also points to Jesus' divinity (cf John 20:28)
annotations.35: [50] Possibly a statement: "You [singular] believe because I saw you under the fig tree."
annotations.36: [51] The double "Amen" is characteristic of John. You is plural in Greek. The allusion is to Jacob's ladder ( Genesis 28:12)

1.verse: Now there was a Pharisee named Nicodemus, a ruler of the Jews.

2.verse: He came to Jesus at night and said to him, "Rabbi, we know that you are a teacher who has come from God, for no one can do these signs that you are doing unless God is with him."

3.verse: Jesus answered and said to him, "Amen, amen, I say to you, no one can see the kingdom of God without being born from above."

4.verse: Nicodemus said to him, "How can a person once grown old be born again? Surely he cannot reenter his mother's womb and be born again, can he?"

5.verse: Jesus answered, "Amen, amen, I say to you, no one can enter the kingdom of God without being born of water and Spirit.

6.verse: What is born of flesh is flesh and what is born of spirit is spirit.

7.verse: Do not be amazed that I told you, 'You must be born from above.'

8.verse: The wind blows where it wills, and you can hear the sound it makes, but you do not know where it comes from or where it goes; so it is with everyone who is born of the Spirit."

9.verse: Nicodemus answered and said to him, "How can this happen?"

10.verse: Jesus answered and said to him, "You are the teacher of Israel and you do not understand this?

11.verse: Amen, amen, I say to you, we speak of what we know and we testify to what we have seen, but you people do not accept our testimony.

12.verse: If I tell you about earthly things and you do not believe, how will you believe if I tell you about heavenly things?

13.verse: No one has gone up to heaven except the one who has come down from heaven, the Son of Man.

14.verse: And just as Moses lifted up the serpent in the desert, so must the Son of Man be lifted up,

15.verse: so that everyone who believes in him may have eternal life."

16.verse: For God so loved the world that he gave his only Son, so that everyone who believes in him might not perish but might have eternal life.

17.verse: For God did not send his Son into the world to condemn the world, but that the world might be saved through him.

18.verse: Whoever believes in him will not be condemned, but whoever does not believe has already been condemned, because he has not believed in the name of the only Son of God.

19.verse: And this is the verdict, that the light came into the world, but people preferred darkness to light, because their works were evil.

20.verse: For everyone who does wicked things hates the light and does not come toward the light, so that his works might not be exposed.

21.verse: But whoever lives the truth comes to the light, so that his works may be clearly seen as done in God.

22.verse: After this, Jesus and his disciples went into the region of Judea, where he spent some time with them baptizing.

23.verse: John was also baptizing in Aenon near Salim, because there was an abundance of water there, and people came to be baptized,

24.verse: for John had not yet been imprisoned.

25.verse: Now a dispute arose between the disciples of John and a Jew about ceremonial washings.

26.verse: So they came to John and said to him, "Rabbi, the one who was with you across the Jordan, to whom you testified, here he is baptizing and everyone is coming to him."

27.verse: John answered and said, "No one can receive anything except what has been given him from heaven.

28.verse: You yourselves can testify that I said (that) I am not the Messiah, but that I was sent before him.

29.verse: The one who has the bride is the bridegroom; the best man, who stands and listens for him, rejoices greatly at the bridegroom's voice. So this joy of mine has been made complete.

30.verse: He must increase; I must decrease."

31.verse: The one who comes from above is above all. The one who is of the earth is earthly and speaks of earthly things. But the one who comes from heaven (is above all).

32.verse: He testifies to what he has seen and heard, but no one accepts his testimony.

33.verse: Whoever does accept his testimony certifies that God is trustworthy.

34.verse: For the one whom God sent speaks the words of God. He does not ration his gift of the Spirit.

35.verse: The Father loves the Son and has given everything over to him.

36.verse: Whoever believes in the Son has eternal life, but whoever disobeys the Son will not see life, but the wrath of God remains upon him.

annotations.1: [1-21] Jesus instructs Nicodemus on the necessity of a new birth from above. This scene in Jerusalem at Passover exemplifies the faith engendered by signs ( John 2:23). It continues the self-manifestation of Jesus in Jerusalem begun in John 2. This is the first of the Johannine discourses, shifting from dialogue to monologue ( John 3:11-15) to reflection of the evangelist ( John 3:16-21). The shift from singular through John 3:10 to plural in John 3:11 may reflect the early church's controversy with the Jews
annotations.2: [1] A ruler of the Jews: most likely a member of the Jewish council, the Sanhedrin; see the note on Mark 8:31.
annotations.3: [3] Born: see the note on John 1:13. From above: the Greek adverb anothen means both "from above" and "again." Jesus means "from above" (see John 3:31) but Nicodemus misunderstands it as "again." This misunderstanding serves as a springboard for further instruction
annotations.4: [8] Wind: the Greek word pneuma (as well as the Hebrew ruah) means both "wind" and "spirit." In the play on the double meaning, "wind" is primary
annotations.5: [14] Lifted up: in Numbers 21:9 Moses simply "mounted" a serpent upon a pole. John here substitutes a verb implying glorification. Jesus, exalted to glory at his cross and resurrection, represents healing for all
annotations.6: [15] Eternal life: used here for the first time in John, this term stresses quality of life rather than duration
annotations.7: [16] Gave: as a gift in the incarnation, and also "over to death" in the crucifixion; cf Romans 8:32
annotations.8: [17-19] Condemn: the Greek root means both judgment and condemnation. Jesus' purpose is to save, but his coming provokes judgment; some condemn themselves by turning from the light
annotations.9: [19] Judgment is not only future but is partially realized here and now
annotations.10: [22-26] Jesus' ministry in Judea is only loosely connected with John 2:13- 3:21; cf John 1:19-36. Perhaps John the Baptist's further testimony was transposed here to give meaning to "water" in John 3:5. Jesus is depicted as baptizing ( John 3:22); contrast John 4:2
annotations.11: [23] Aenon near Salim: site uncertain, either in the upper Jordan valley or in Samaria
annotations.12: [24] A remark probably intended to avoid objections based on a chronology like that of the synoptics ( Matthew 4:12; Mark 1:14)
annotations.13: [25] A Jew: some think Jesus is meant. Many manuscripts read "Jews."
annotations.14: [29] The best man: literally, "the friend of the groom," the shoshben of Jewish tradition, who arranged the wedding. Competition between him and the groom would be unthinkable
annotations.15: [31-36] It is uncertain whether these are words by the Baptist, Jesus, or the evangelist. They are reflections on the two preceding scenes
annotations.16: [34] His gift: of God or to Jesus, perhaps both. This verse echoes John 5:8

1.verse: "Amen, amen, I say to you, whoever does not enter a sheepfold through the gate but climbs over elsewhere is a thief and a robber.

2.verse: But whoever enters through the gate is the shepherd of the sheep.

3.verse: The gatekeeper opens it for him, and the sheep hear his voice, as he calls his own sheep by name and leads them out.

4.verse: When he has driven out all his own, he walks ahead of them, and the sheep follow him, because they recognize his voice.

5.verse: But they will not follow a stranger; they will run away from him, because they do not recognize the voice of strangers."

6.verse: Although Jesus used this figure of speech, they did not realize what he was trying to tell them.

7.verse: So Jesus said again, "Amen, amen, I say to you, I am the gate for the sheep.

8.verse: All who came [before me] are thieves and robbers, but the sheep did not listen to them.

9.verse: I am the gate. Whoever enters through me will be saved, and will come in and go out and find pasture.

10.verse: A thief comes only to steal and slaughter and destroy; I came so that they might have life and have it more abundantly.

11.verse: I am the good shepherd. A good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep.

12.verse: A hired man, who is not a shepherd and whose sheep are not his own, sees a wolf coming and leaves the sheep and runs away, and the wolf catches and scatters them.

13.verse: This is because he works for pay and has no concern for the sheep.

14.verse: I am the good shepherd, and I know mine and mine know me,

15.verse: just as the Father knows me and I know the Father; and I will lay down my life for the sheep.

16.verse: I have other sheep that do not belong to this fold. These also I must lead, and they will hear my voice, and there will be one flock, one shepherd.

17.verse: This is why the Father loves me, because I lay down my life in order to take it up again.

18.verse: No one takes it from me, but I lay it down on my own. I have power to lay it down, and power to take it up again. This command I have received from my Father."

19.verse: Again there was a division among the Jews because of these words.

20.verse: Many of them said, "He is possessed and out of his mind; why listen to him?"

21.verse: Others said, "These are not the words of one possessed; surely a demon cannot open the eyes of the blind, can he?"

22.verse: The feast of the Dedication was then taking place in Jerusalem. It was winter.

23.verse: And Jesus walked about in the temple area on the Portico of Solomon.

24.verse: So the Jews gathered around him and said to him, "How long are you going to keep us in suspense? If you are the Messiah, tell us plainly."

25.verse: Jesus answered them, "I told you and you do not believe. The works I do in my Father's name testify to me.

26.verse: But you do not believe, because you are not among my sheep.

27.verse: My sheep hear my voice; I know them, and they follow me.

28.verse: I give them eternal life, and they shall never perish. No one can take them out of my hand.

29.verse: My Father, who has given them to me, is greater than all, and no one can take them out of the Father's hand.

30.verse: The Father and I are one."

31.verse: The Jews again picked up rocks to stone him.

32.verse: Jesus answered them, "I have shown you many good works from my Father. For which of these are you trying to stone me?"

33.verse: The Jews answered him, "We are not stoning you for a good work but for blasphemy. You, a man, are making yourself God."

34.verse: Jesus answered them, "Is it not written in your law, 'I said, "You are gods"'?

35.verse: If it calls them gods to whom the word of God came, and scripture cannot be set aside,

36.verse: can you say that the one whom the Father has consecrated and sent into the world blasphemes because I said, 'I am the Son of God'?

37.verse: If I do not perform my Father's works, do not believe me;

38.verse: but if I perform them, even if you do not believe me, believe the works, so that you may realize (and understand) that the Father is in me and I am in the Father."

39.verse: (Then) they tried again to arrest him; but he escaped from their power.

40.verse: He went back across the Jordan to the place where John first baptized, and there he remained.

41.verse: Many came to him and said, "John performed no sign, but everything John said about this man was true."

42.verse: And many there began to believe in him.

annotations.1: [1-21] The good shepherd discourse continues the theme of attack on the Pharisees that ends John 9. The figure is allegorical: the hired hands are the Pharisees who excommunicated the cured blind man. It serves as a commentary on John 9. For the shepherd motif, used of Yahweh in the Old Testament, cf Exodus 34; Genesis 48:15; 49:24; Micah 7:14; Psalm 23:1-4; 80:1
annotations.2: [1] Sheepfold: a low stone wall open to the sky.
annotations.3: [4] Recognize his voice: the Pharisees do not recognize Jesus, but the people of God, symbolized by the blind man, do
annotations.4: [6] Figure of speech: John uses a different word for illustrative speech than the "parable" of the synoptics, but the idea is similar
annotations.5: [7-10] In John 10:7-8, the figure is of a gate for the shepherd to come to the sheep; in John 10:9-10, the figure is of a gate for the sheep to come in and go out
annotations.6: [8] [Before me]: these words are omitted in many good early manuscripts and versions
annotations.7: [16] Other sheep: the Gentiles, possibly a reference to "God's dispersed children" of John 11:52 destined to be gathered into one, or "apostolic Christians" at odds with the community of the beloved disciple
annotations.8: [18] Power to take it up again: contrast the role of the Father as the efficient cause of the resurrection in Acts 2:24; 4:10; etc.; Romans 1:4; 4:24. Yet even here is added: This command I have received from my Father
annotations.9: [22] Feast of the Dedication: an eight-day festival of lights (Hebrew, Hanukkah) held in December, three months after the feast of Tabernacles ( John 7:2), to celebrate the Maccabees' rededication of the altar and reconsecration of the temple in 164 B.C., after their desecration by Antiochus IV Epiphanes ( Daniel 8:13; 9:27; cf 1 Macc 4:36-59; 2 Macc 1:18- 2:19; 10:1-8)
annotations.10: [23] Portico of Solomon: on the east side of the temple area, offering protection against the cold winds from the desert
annotations.11: [24] Keep us in suspense: literally, "How long will you take away our life?" Cf John 11:48-50. If you are the Messiah, tell us plainly: cf Luke 22:67. This is the climax of Jesus' encounters with the Jewish authorities. There has never yet been an open confession before them
annotations.12: [25] I told you: probably at John 8:25 which was an evasive answer
annotations.13: [29] The textual evidence for the first clause is very divided; it may also be translated: "As for the Father, what he has given me is greater than all," or "My Father is greater than all, in what he has given me."
annotations.14: [30] This is justification for John 10:29; it asserts unity of power and reveals that the words and deeds of Jesus are the words and deeds of God
annotations.15: [34] This is a reference to the judges of Israel who,since they exercised the divine prerogative to judge ( Deut 1:17), were called "gods"; cf Exodus 21:6, besides Psalm 82:6 from which the quotation comes
annotations.16: [36] Consecrated: this may be a reference to the rededicated altar at the Hanukkah feast; see the note on John 10:22
annotations.17: [41] Performed no sign: this is to stress the inferior role of John the Baptist. The Transjordan topography recalls the great witness of John the Baptist to Jesus, as opposed to the hostility of the authorities in Jerusalem

1.verse: When Jesus had said this, he raised his eyes to heaven and said, "Father, the hour has come. Give glory to your son, so that your son may glorify you,

2.verse: just as you gave him authority over all people, so that he may give eternal life to all you gave him.

3.verse: Now this is eternal life, that they should know you, the only true God, and the one whom you sent, Jesus Christ.

4.verse: I glorified you on earth by accomplishing the work that you gave me to do.

5.verse: Now glorify me, Father, with you, with the glory that I had with you before the world began.

6.verse: "I revealed your name to those whom you gave me out of the world. They belonged to you, and you gave them to me, and they have kept your word.

7.verse: Now they know that everything you gave me is from you,

8.verse: because the words you gave to me I have given to them, and they accepted them and truly understood that I came from you, and they have believed that you sent me.

9.verse: I pray for them. I do not pray for the world but for the ones you have given me, because they are yours,

10.verse: and everything of mine is yours and everything of yours is mine, and I have been glorified in them.

11.verse: And now I will no longer be in the world, but they are in the world, while I am coming to you. Holy Father, keep them in your name that you have given me, so that they may be one just as we are.

12.verse: When I was with them I protected them in your name that you gave me, and I guarded them, and none of them was lost except the son of destruction, in order that the scripture might be fulfilled.

13.verse: But now I am coming to you. I speak this in the world so that they may share my joy completely.

14.verse: I gave them your word, and the world hated them, because they do not belong to the world any more than I belong to the world.

15.verse: I do not ask that you take them out of the world but that you keep them from the evil one.

16.verse: They do not belong to the world any more than I belong to the world.

17.verse: Consecrate them in the truth. Your word is truth.

18.verse: As you sent me into the world, so I sent them into the world.

19.verse: And I consecrate myself for them, so that they also may be consecrated in truth.

20.verse: "I pray not only for them, but also for those who will believe in me through their word,

21.verse: so that they may all be one, as you, Father, are in me and I in you, that they also may be in us, that the world may believe that you sent me.

22.verse: And I have given them the glory you gave me, so that they may be one, as we are one,

23.verse: I in them and you in me, that they may be brought to perfection as one, that the world may know that you sent me, and that you loved them even as you loved me.

24.verse: Father, they are your gift to me. I wish that where I am they also may be with me, that they may see my glory that you gave me, because you loved me before the foundation of the world.

25.verse: Righteous Father, the world also does not know you, but I know you, and they know that you sent me.

26.verse: I made known to them your name and I will make it known, that the love with which you loved me may be in them and I in them."

annotations.1: [1-26] Climax of the last discourse(s). Since the sixteenth century, this chapter has been called the "high priestly prayer" of Jesus. He speaks as intercessor, with words addressed directly to the Father and not to the disciples, who supposedly only overhear. Yet the prayer is one of petition, for immediate ( John 17:6-19) and future ( John 17:20-21) disciples. Many phrases reminiscent of the Lord's Prayer occur. Although still in the world ( John 17:13), Jesus looks on his earthly ministry as a thing of the past ( John 17:4, 12). Whereas Jesus has up to this time stated that the disciples could follow him ( John 13:33, 36), now he wishes them to be with him in union with the Father ( John 17:12-14)
annotations.2: [1] The action of looking up to heaven and the address Father are typical of Jesus at prayer; cf John 11:41 and Luke 11:2.
annotations.3: [2] Another possible interpretation is to treat the first line of the verse as parenthetical and the second as an appositive to the clause that ends v 1: so that your son may glorify you (just as . . . all people), so that he may give eternal life. . .
annotations.4: [3] This verse was clearly added in the editing of the gospel as a reflection on the preceding verse; Jesus nowhere else refers to himself as Jesus Christ
annotations.5: [6] I revealed your name: perhaps the name I AM; cf John 8:24, 28, 58; 13:19
annotations.6: [15] Note the resemblance to the petition of the Lord's Prayer, "deliver us from the evil one." Both probably refer to the devil rather than to abstract evil
annotations.7: [24] Where I am: Jesus prays for the believers ultimately to join him in heaven. Then they will not see his glory as in a mirror but clearly ( 2 Cor 3:18; 1 John 3:2)
annotations.8: [26] I will make it known: through the Advocate

1.verse: Now when Jesus learned that the Pharisees had heard that Jesus was making and baptizing more disciples than John

2.verse: (although Jesus himself was not baptizing, just his disciples),

3.verse: he left Judea and returned to Galilee.

4.verse: He had to pass through Samaria.

5.verse: So he came to a town of Samaria called Sychar, near the plot of land that Jacob had given to his son Joseph.

6.verse: Jacob's well was there. Jesus, tired from his journey, sat down there at the well. It was about noon.

7.verse: A woman of Samaria came to draw water. Jesus said to her, "Give me a drink."

8.verse: His disciples had gone into the town to buy food.

9.verse: The Samaritan woman said to him, "How can you, a Jew, ask me, a Samaritan woman, for a drink?" (For Jews use nothing in common with Samaritans.)

10.verse: Jesus answered and said to her, "If you knew the gift of God and who is saying to you, 'Give me a drink,' you would have asked him and he would have given you living water."

11.verse: (The woman) said to him, "Sir, you do not even have a bucket and the cistern is deep; where then can you get this living water?

12.verse: Are you greater than our father Jacob, who gave us this cistern and drank from it himself with his children and his flocks?"

13.verse: Jesus answered and said to her, "Everyone who drinks this water will be thirsty again;

14.verse: but whoever drinks the water I shall give will never thirst; the water I shall give will become in him a spring of water welling up to eternal life."

15.verse: The woman said to him, "Sir, give me this water, so that I may not be thirsty or have to keep coming here to draw water."

16.verse: Jesus said to her, "Go call your husband and come back."

17.verse: The woman answered and said to him, "I do not have a husband." Jesus answered her, "You are right in saying, 'I do not have a husband.'

18.verse: For you have had five husbands, and the one you have now is not your husband. What you have said is true."

19.verse: The woman said to him, "Sir, I can see that you are a prophet.

20.verse: Our ancestors worshiped on this mountain; but you people say that the place to worship is in Jerusalem."

21.verse: Jesus said to her, "Believe me, woman, the hour is coming when you will worship the Father neither on this mountain nor in Jerusalem.

22.verse: You people worship what you do not understand; we worship what we understand, because salvation is from the Jews.

23.verse: But the hour is coming, and is now here, when true worshipers will worship the Father in Spirit and truth; and indeed the Father seeks such people to worship him.

24.verse: God is Spirit, and those who worship him must worship in Spirit and truth."

25.verse: The woman said to him, "I know that the Messiah is coming, the one called the Anointed; when he comes, he will tell us everything."

26.verse: Jesus said to her, "I am he, the one who is speaking with you."

27.verse: At that moment his disciples returned, and were amazed that he was talking with a woman, but still no one said, "What are you looking for?" or "Why are you talking with her?"

28.verse: The woman left her water jar and went into the town and said to the people,

29.verse: "Come see a man who told me everything I have done. Could he possibly be the Messiah?"

30.verse: They went out of the town and came to him.

31.verse: Meanwhile, the disciples urged him, "Rabbi, eat."

32.verse: But he said to them, "I have food to eat of which you do not know."

33.verse: So the disciples said to one another, "Could someone have brought him something to eat?"

34.verse: Jesus said to them, "My food is to do the will of the one who sent me and to finish his work.

35.verse: Do you not say, 'In four months the harvest will be here'? I tell you, look up and see the fields ripe for the harvest.

36.verse: The reaper is already receiving his payment and gathering crops for eternal life, so that the sower and reaper can rejoice together.

37.verse: For here the saying is verified that 'One sows and another reaps.'

38.verse: I sent you to reap what you have not worked for; others have done the work, and you are sharing the fruits of their work."

39.verse: Many of the Samaritans of that town began to believe in him because of the word of the woman who testified, "He told me everything I have done."

40.verse: When the Samaritans came to him, they invited him to stay with them; and he stayed there two days.

41.verse: Many more began to believe in him because of his word,

42.verse: and they said to the woman, "We no longer believe because of your word; for we have heard for ourselves, and we know that this is truly the savior of the world."

43.verse: After the two days, he left there for Galilee.

44.verse: For Jesus himself testified that a prophet has no honor in his native place.

45.verse: When he came into Galilee, the Galileans welcomed him, since they had seen all he had done in Jerusalem at the feast; for they themselves had gone to the feast.

46.verse: Then he returned to Cana in Galilee, where he had made the water wine. Now there was a royal official whose son was ill in Capernaum.

47.verse: When he heard that Jesus had arrived in Galilee from Judea, he went to him and asked him to come down and heal his son, who was near death.

48.verse: Jesus said to him, "Unless you people see signs and wonders, you will not believe."

49.verse: The royal official said to him, "Sir, come down before my child dies."

50.verse: Jesus said to him, "You may go; your son will live." The man believed what Jesus said to him and left.

51.verse: While he was on his way back, his slaves met him and told him that his boy would live.

52.verse: He asked them when he began to recover. They told him, "The fever left him yesterday, about one in the afternoon."

53.verse: The father realized that just at that time Jesus had said to him, "Your son will live," and he and his whole household came to believe.

54.verse: (Now) this was the second sign Jesus did when he came to Galilee from Judea.

annotations.1: [1-42] Jesus in Samaria. The self-revelation of Jesus continues with his second discourse, on his mission to "half-Jews." It continues the theme of replacement, here with regard to cult ( John 4:21). Water ( John 4:7-15) serves as a symbol (as at Cana and in the Nicodemus episode).
annotations.2: [2] An editorial refinement of John 3:22, perhaps directed against followers of John the Baptist who claimed that Jesus imitated him
annotations.3: [4] He had to: a theological necessity; geographically, Jews often bypassed Samaria by taking a route across the Jordan
annotations.4: [5] Sychar: Jerome identifies this with Shechem, a reading found in Syriac manuscripts
annotations.5: [9] Samaritan women were regarded by Jews as ritually impure, and therefore Jews were forbidden to drink from any vessel they had handled
annotations.6: [10] Living water: the water of life, i.e., the revelation that Jesus brings; the woman thinks of "flowing water," so much more desirable than stagnant cistern water. On John's device of such misunderstanding, cf the note on John 3:3
annotations.7: [11] Sir: the Greek kyrios means "master" or "lord," as a respectful mode of address for a human being or a deity; cf John 4:19. It is also the word used in the Septuagint for the Hebrew 'adonai, substituted for the tetragrammaton YHWH
annotations.8: [20] This mountain: Gerizim, on which a temple was erected in the fourth century B.C. by Samaritans to rival Matthew. Zion in Jerusalem; cf Deut 27:4 (Mount Ebal = the Jews' term for Gerizim)
annotations.9: [23] In Spirit and truth: not a reference to an interior worship within one's own spirit. The Spirit is the spirit given by God that reveals truth and enables one to worship God appropriately ( John 14:16-17). Cf "born of water and Spirit ( John 3:5)
annotations.10: [25] The expectations of the Samaritans are expressed here in Jewish terminology. They did not expect a messianic king of the house of David but a prophet like Moses ( Deut 18:15)
annotations.11: [26] I am he: it could also be translated "I am," an Old Testament self-designation of Yahweh ( Isaiah 43:3, etc.); cf John 6:20; 8:24, 28, 58; 13:19; 18:5-6, 8. See the note on Mark 6:50
annotations.12: [27] Talking with a woman: a religious and social restriction that Jesus is pictured treating as unimportant
annotations.13: [35] "In four months . . .': probably a proverb; cf Matthew 9:37-38
annotations.14: [36] Already: this word may go with the preceding verse rather than with John 4:36
annotations.15: [39] The woman is presented as a missionary, described in virtually the same words as the disciples are in Jesus' prayer ( John 17:20)
annotations.16: [43-54] Jesus' arrival in Cana in Galilee; the second sign. This section introduces another theme, that of the life-giving word of Jesus. It is explicitly linked to the first sign ( John 2:11). The royal official believes ( John 4:50). The natural life given his son is a sign of eternal life
annotations.17: [44] Probably a reminiscence of a tradition as in Mark 6:4. Cf Gospel of Thomas John 4:31: "No prophet is acceptable in his village, no physician heals those who know him."
annotations.18: [46-54] The story of the cure of the royal official's son may be a third version of the cure of the centurion's son ( Matthew 8:5-13) or servant ( Luke 7:1-10). Cf also Matthew 15:21-28; Mark 7:24-30

1.verse: Before the feast of Passover, Jesus knew that his hour had come to pass from this world to the Father. He loved his own in the world and he loved them to the end.

2.verse: The devil had already induced Judas, son of Simon the Iscariot, to hand him over. So, during supper,

3.verse: fully aware that the Father had put everything into his power and that he had come from God and was returning to God,

4.verse: he rose from supper and took off his outer garments. He took a towel and tied it around his waist.

5.verse: Then he poured water into a basin and began to wash the disciples' feet and dry them with the towel around his waist.

6.verse: He came to Simon Peter, who said to him, "Master, are you going to wash my feet?"

7.verse: Jesus answered and said to him, "What I am doing, you do not understand now, but you will understand later."

8.verse: Peter said to him, "You will never wash my feet." Jesus answered him, "Unless I wash you, you will have no inheritance with me."

9.verse: Simon Peter said to him, "Master, then not only my feet, but my hands and head as well."

10.verse: Jesus said to him, "Whoever has bathed has no need except to have his feet washed, for he is clean all over; so you are clean, but not all."

11.verse: For he knew who would betray him; for this reason, he said, "Not all of you are clean."

12.verse: So when he had washed their feet (and) put his garments back on and reclined at table again, he said to them, "Do you realize what I have done for you?

13.verse: You call me 'teacher' and 'master,' and rightly so, for indeed I am.

14.verse: If I, therefore, the master and teacher, have washed your feet, you ought to wash one another's feet.

15.verse: I have given you a model to follow, so that as I have done for you, you should also do.

16.verse: Amen, amen, I say to you, no slave is greater than his master nor any messenger greater than the one who sent him.

17.verse: If you understand this, blessed are you if you do it.

18.verse: I am not speaking of all of you. I know those whom I have chosen. But so that the scripture might be fulfilled, 'The one who ate my food has raised his heel against me.'

19.verse: From now on I am telling you before it happens, so that when it happens you may believe that I AM.

20.verse: Amen, amen, I say to you, whoever receives the one I send receives me, and whoever receives me receives the one who sent me."

21.verse: When he had said this, Jesus was deeply troubled and testified, "Amen, amen, I say to you, one of you will betray me."

22.verse: The disciples looked at one another, at a loss as to whom he meant.

23.verse: One of his disciples, the one whom Jesus loved, was reclining at Jesus' side.

24.verse: So Simon Peter nodded to him to find out whom he meant.

25.verse: He leaned back against Jesus' chest and said to him, "Master, who is it?"

26.verse: Jesus answered, "It is the one to whom I hand the morsel after I have dipped it." So he dipped the morsel and (took it and) handed it to Judas, son of Simon the Iscariot.

27.verse: After he took the morsel, Satan entered him. So Jesus said to him, "What you are going to do, do quickly."

28.verse: (Now) none of those reclining at table realized why he said this to him.

29.verse: Some thought that since Judas kept the money bag, Jesus had told him, "Buy what we need for the feast," or to give something to the poor.

30.verse: So he took the morsel and left at once. And it was night.

31.verse: When he had left, Jesus said, "Now is the Son of Man glorified, and God is glorified in him.

32.verse: (If God is glorified in him,) God will also glorify him in himself, and he will glorify him at once.

33.verse: My children, I will be with you only a little while longer. You will look for me, and as I told the Jews, 'Where I go you cannot come,' so now I say it to you.

34.verse: I give you a new commandment: love one another. As I have loved you, so you also should love one another.

35.verse: This is how all will know that you are my disciples, if you have love for one another."

36.verse: Simon Peter said to him, "Master, where are you going?" Jesus answered (him), "Where I am going, you cannot follow me now, though you will follow later."

37.verse: Peter said to him, "Master, why can't I follow you now? I will lay down my life for you."

38.verse: Jesus answered, "Will you lay down your life for me? Amen, amen, I say to you, the cock will not crow before you deny me three times."

annotations.1: [ 13:1- 19:42] The Book of Glory. There is a major break here; the word "sign" is used again only in John 20:30. In this phase of Jesus' return to the Father, the discourses (John 13-17) precede the traditional narrative of the passion (John 18-20) to interpret them for the Christian reader. This is the only extended example of esoteric teaching of disciples in John
annotations.2: [1-20] Washing of the disciples' feet. This episode occurs in John at the place of the narration of the institution of the Eucharist in the synoptics. It may be a dramatization of Luke 22:27 - "I am your servant." It is presented as a "model" ("pattern") of the crucifixion. It symbolizes cleansing from sin by sacrificial death
annotations.3: [1] Before the feast of Passover: this would be Thursday evening, before the day of preparation; in the synoptics, the Last Supper is a Passover meal taking place, in John's chronology, on Friday evening. To the end: or, "completely."
annotations.4: [2] Induced: literally, "The devil put into the heart that Judas should hand him over."
annotations.5: [5] The act of washing another's feet was one that could not be required of the lowliest Jewish slave. It is an allusion to the humiliating death of the crucifixion
annotations.6: [10] Bathed: many have suggested that this passage is a symbolic reference to baptism. The Greek root involved is used in baptismal contexts in 1 Cor 6:11; Eph 5:26; Titus 3:5; Hebrews 10:22
annotations.7: [16] Messenger: the Greek has apostolos, the only occurrence of the term in John. It is not used in the technical sense here
annotations.8: [23] The one whom Jesus loved: also mentioned in John 19:26; 20:2; 21:7. A disciple, called "another disciple" or "the other disciple," is mentioned in John 18:15 and John 20:2; in the latter reference he is identified with the disciple whom Jesus loved. There is also an unnamed disciple in John 1:35-40; see the note on John 1:37
annotations.9: [26] Morsel: probably the bitter herb dipped in salt water
annotations.10: [ 13:31- 17:26] Two farewell discourses and a prayer. These seem to be Johannine compositions, including sayings of Jesus at the Last Supper and on other occasions, modeled on similar farewell discourses in Greek literature and the Old Testament (of Moses, Joshua, David)
annotations.11: [31-38] Introduction: departure and return. Terms of coming and going predominate. These verses form an introduction to the last discourse of Jesus, which extends through John 14-17. In it John has collected Jesus' words to his own ( John 13:1). There are indications that several speeches have been fused together, e.g., in John 14:31 and John 17:1
annotations.12: [34] I give you a new commandment: this puts Jesus on a par with Yahweh. The commandment itself is not new; cf Lev 19:18 and the note there

1.verse: On the first day of the week, Mary of Magdala came to the tomb early in the morning, while it was still dark, and saw the stone removed from the tomb.

2.verse: So she ran and went to Simon Peter and to the other disciple whom Jesus loved, and told them, "They have taken the Lord from the tomb, and we don't know where they put him."

3.verse: So Peter and the other disciple went out and came to the tomb.

4.verse: They both ran, but the other disciple ran faster than Peter and arrived at the tomb first;

5.verse: he bent down and saw the burial cloths there, but did not go in.

6.verse: When Simon Peter arrived after him, he went into the tomb and saw the burial cloths there,

7.verse: and the cloth that had covered his head, not with the burial cloths but rolled up in a separate place.

8.verse: Then the other disciple also went in, the one who had arrived at the tomb first, and he saw and believed.

9.verse: For they did not yet understand the scripture that he had to rise from the dead.

10.verse: Then the disciples returned home.

11.verse: But Mary stayed outside the tomb weeping. And as she wept, she bent over into the tomb

12.verse: and saw two angels in white sitting there, one at the head and one at the feet where the body of Jesus had been.

13.verse: And they said to her, "Woman, why are you weeping?" She said to them, "They have taken my Lord, and I don't know where they laid him."

14.verse: When she had said this, she turned around and saw Jesus there, but did not know it was Jesus.

15.verse: Jesus said to her, "Woman, why are you weeping? Whom are you looking for?" She thought it was the gardener and said to him, "Sir, if you carried him away, tell me where you laid him, and I will take him."

16.verse: Jesus said to her, "Mary!" She turned and said to him in Hebrew, "Rabbouni," which means Teacher.

17.verse: Jesus said to her, "Stop holding on to me, for I have not yet ascended to the Father. But go to my brothers and tell them, 'I am going to my Father and your Father, to my God and your God.'"

18.verse: Mary of Magdala went and announced to the disciples, "I have seen the Lord," and what he told her.

19.verse: On the evening of that first day of the week, when the doors were locked, where the disciples were, for fear of the Jews, Jesus came and stood in their midst and said to them, "Peace be with you."

20.verse: When he had said this, he showed them his hands and his side. The disciples rejoiced when they saw the Lord.

21.verse: (Jesus) said to them again, "Peace be with you. As the Father has sent me, so I send you."

22.verse: And when he had said this, he breathed on them and said to them, "Receive the holy Spirit.

23.verse: Whose sins you forgive are forgiven them, and whose sins you retain are retained."

24.verse: Thomas, called Didymus, one of the Twelve, was not with them when Jesus came.

25.verse: So the other disciples said to him, "We have seen the Lord." But he said to them, "Unless I see the mark of the nails in his hands and put my finger into the nailmarks and put my hand into his side, I will not believe."

26.verse: Now a week later his disciples were again inside and Thomas was with them. Jesus came, although the doors were locked, and stood in their midst and said, "Peace be with you."

27.verse: Then he said to Thomas, "Put your finger here and see my hands, and bring your hand and put it into my side, and do not be unbelieving, but believe."

28.verse: Thomas answered and said to him, "My Lord and my God!"

29.verse: Jesus said to him, "Have you come to believe because you have seen me? Blessed are those who have not seen and have believed."

30.verse: Now Jesus did many other signs in the presence of (his) disciples that are not written in this book.

31.verse: But these are written that you may (come to) believe that Jesus is the Messiah, the Son of God, and that through this belief you may have life in his name.

annotations.1: [1-31] The risen Jesus reveals his glory and confers the Spirit. This story fulfills the basic need for testimony to the resurrection. What we have here is not a record but a series of single stories
annotations.2: [1-10] The story of the empty tomb is found in both the Matthean and the Lucan traditions; John's version seems to be a fusion of the two
annotations.3: [1] Still dark: according to Mark the sun had risen, Matthew describes it as "dawning," and Luke refers to early dawn. Mary sees the stone removed, not the empty tomb.
annotations.4: [2] Mary runs away, not directed by an angel/young man as in the synoptic accounts. The plural "we" in the second part of her statement might reflect a tradition of more women going to the tomb
annotations.5: [3-10] The basic narrative is told of Peter alone in Luke 24:12, a verse missing in important manuscripts and which may be borrowed from tradition similar to John. Cf also Luke 24:24
annotations.6: [6-8] Some special feature about the state of the burial cloths caused the beloved disciple to believe. Perhaps the details emphasized that the grave had not been robbed
annotations.7: [9] Probably a general reference to the scriptures is intended, as in Luke 24:26 and 1 Cor 15:4. Some individual Old Testament passages suggested are Psalm 16:10; Hosea 6:2; Jonah 2:1, 2, 10
annotations.8: [11-18] This appearance to Mary is found only in John, but cf Matthew 28:8-10 and Mark 16:9-11
annotations.9: [16] Rabbouni: Hebrew or Aramaic for "my master."
annotations.10: [17] Stop holding on to me: see Matthew 28:9, where the women take hold of his feet. I have not yet ascended: for John and many of the New Testament writers, the ascension in the theological sense of going to the Father to be glorified took place with the resurrection as one action. This scene in John dramatizes such an understanding, for by Easter night Jesus is glorified and can give the Spirit. Therefore his ascension takes place immediately after he has talked to Mary. In such a view, the ascension after forty days described in Acts 1:1-11 would be simply a termination of earthly appearances or, perhaps better, an introduction to the conferral of the Spirit upon the early church, modeled on Elisha's being able to have a (double) share in the spirit of Elijah if he saw him being taken up (same verb as ascending) into heaven ( 2 Kings 2:9-12). To my Father and your Father, to my God and your God: this echoes Ruth 1:16: "Your people shall be my people, and your God my God." The Father of Jesus will now become the Father of the disciples because, once ascended, Jesus can give them the Spirit that comes from the Father and they can be reborn as God's children ( John 3:5). That is why he calls them my brothers
annotations.11: [19-29] The appearances to the disciples, without or with Thomas (cf John 11:16; 14:5), have rough parallels in the other gospels only for John 20:19-23; cf Luke 24:36-39; Mark 16:14-18
annotations.12: [19] The disciples: by implication from John 20:24 this means ten of the Twelve, presumably in Jerusalem. Peace be with you: although this could be an ordinary greeting, John intends here to echo John 14:27. The theme of rejoicing in John 20:20 echoes John 16:22
annotations.13: [20] Hands and . . . side: Luke 24:39-40 mentions "hands and feet," based on Psalm 22:17
annotations.14: [21] By means of this sending, the Eleven were made apostles, that is, "those sent" (cf John 17:18), though John does not use the noun in reference to them (see the note on John 13:16). A solemn mission or "sending" is also the subject of the post-resurrection appearances to the Eleven in Matthew 28:19; Luke 24:47; Mark 16:15
annotations.15: [22] This action recalls Genesis 2:7, where God breathed on the first man and gave him life; just as Adam's life came from God, so now the disciples' new spiritual life comes from Jesus. Cf also the revivification of the dry bones in Ezekial 37. This is the author's version of Pentecost. Cf also the note on John 19:30
annotations.16: [23] The Council of Trent defined that this power to forgive sins is exercised in the sacrament of penance. See Matthew 16:19; Matthew 18:18
annotations.17: [28] My Lord and my God: this forms a literary inclusion with the first verse of the gospel: "and the Word was God."
annotations.18: [29] This verse is a beatitude on future generations; faith, not sight, matters
annotations.19: [30-31] These verses are clearly a conclusion to the gospel and express its purpose. While many manuscripts read come to believe, possibly implying a missionary purpose for John's gospel, a small number of quite early ones read "continue to believe," suggesting that the audience consists of Christians whose faith is to be deepened by the book; cf John 19:35

1.verse: Now a man was ill, Lazarus from Bethany, the village of Mary and her sister Martha.

2.verse: Mary was the one who had anointed the Lord with perfumed oil and dried his feet with her hair; it was her brother Lazarus who was ill.

3.verse: So the sisters sent word to him, saying, "Master, the one you love is ill."

4.verse: When Jesus heard this he said, "This illness is not to end in death, but is for the glory of God, that the Son of God may be glorified through it."

5.verse: Now Jesus loved Martha and her sister and Lazarus.

6.verse: So when he heard that he was ill, he remained for two days in the place where he was.

7.verse: Then after this he said to his disciples, "Let us go back to Judea."

8.verse: The disciples said to him, "Rabbi, the Jews were just trying to stone you, and you want to go back there?"

9.verse: Jesus answered, "Are there not twelve hours in a day? If one walks during the day, he does not stumble, because he sees the light of this world.

10.verse: But if one walks at night, he stumbles, because the light is not in him."

11.verse: He said this, and then told them, "Our friend Lazarus is asleep, but I am going to awaken him."

12.verse: So the disciples said to him, "Master, if he is asleep, he will be saved."

13.verse: But Jesus was talking about his death, while they thought that he meant ordinary sleep.

14.verse: So then Jesus said to them clearly, "Lazarus has died.

15.verse: And I am glad for you that I was not there, that you may believe. Let us go to him."

16.verse: So Thomas, called Didymus, said to his fellow disciples, "Let us also go to die with him."

17.verse: When Jesus arrived, he found that Lazarus had already been in the tomb for four days.

18.verse: Now Bethany was near Jerusalem, only about two miles away.

19.verse: And many of the Jews had come to Martha and Mary to comfort them about their brother.

20.verse: When Martha heard that Jesus was coming, she went to meet him; but Mary sat at home.

21.verse: Martha said to Jesus, "Lord, if you had been here, my brother would not have died.

22.verse: (But) even now I know that whatever you ask of God, God will give you."

23.verse: Jesus said to her, "Your brother will rise."

24.verse: Martha said to him, "I know he will rise, in the resurrection on the last day."

25.verse: Jesus told her, "I am the resurrection and the life; whoever believes in me, even if he dies, will live,

26.verse: and everyone who lives and believes in me will never die. Do you believe this?"

27.verse: She said to him, "Yes, Lord. I have come to believe that you are the Messiah, the Son of God, the one who is coming into the world."

28.verse: When she had said this, she went and called her sister Mary secretly, saying, "The teacher is here and is asking for you."

29.verse: As soon as she heard this, she rose quickly and went to him.

30.verse: For Jesus had not yet come into the village, but was still where Martha had met him.

31.verse: So when the Jews who were with her in the house comforting her saw Mary get up quickly and go out, they followed her, presuming that she was going to the tomb to weep there.

32.verse: When Mary came to where Jesus was and saw him, she fell at his feet and said to him, "Lord, if you had been here, my brother would not have died."

33.verse: When Jesus saw her weeping and the Jews who had come with her weeping, he became perturbed and deeply troubled,

34.verse: and said, "Where have you laid him?" They said to him, "Sir, come and see."

36.verse: So the Jews said, "See how he loved him."

37.verse: But some of them said, "Could not the one who opened the eyes of the blind man have done something so that this man would not have died?"

38.verse: So Jesus, perturbed again, came to the tomb. It was a cave, and a stone lay across it.

39.verse: Jesus said, "Take away the stone." Martha, the dead man's sister, said to him, "Lord, by now there will be a stench; he has been dead for four days."

40.verse: Jesus said to her, "Did I not tell you that if you believe you will see the glory of God?"

41.verse: So they took away the stone. And Jesus raised his eyes and said, "Father, I thank you for hearing me.

42.verse: I know that you always hear me; but because of the crowd here I have said this, that they may believe that you sent me."

43.verse: And when he had said this, he cried out in a loud voice, "Lazarus, come out!"

44.verse: The dead man came out, tied hand and foot with burial bands, and his face was wrapped in a cloth. So Jesus said to them, "Untie him and let him go."

45.verse: Now many of the Jews who had come to Mary and seen what he had done began to believe in him.

46.verse: But some of them went to the Pharisees and told them what Jesus had done.

47.verse: So the chief priests and the Pharisees convened the Sanhedrin and said, "What are we going to do? This man is performing many signs.

48.verse: If we leave him alone, all will believe in him, and the Romans will come and take away both our land and our nation."

49.verse: But one of them, Caiaphas, who was high priest that year, said to them, "You know nothing,

50.verse: nor do you consider that it is better for you that one man should die instead of the people, so that the whole nation may not perish."

51.verse: He did not say this on his own, but since he was high priest for that year, he prophesied that Jesus was going to die for the nation,

52.verse: and not only for the nation, but also to gather into one the dispersed children of God.

53.verse: So from that day on they planned to kill him.

54.verse: So Jesus no longer walked about in public among the Jews, but he left for the region near the desert, to a town called Ephraim, and there he remained with his disciples.

55.verse: Now the Passover of the Jews was near, and many went up from the country to Jerusalem before Passover to purify themselves.

56.verse: They looked for Jesus and said to one another as they were in the temple area, "What do you think? That he will not come to the feast?"

57.verse: For the chief priests and the Pharisees had given orders that if anyone knew where he was, he should inform them, so that they might arrest him.

annotations.1: [1-44] The raising of Lazarus, the longest continuous narrative in John outside of the passion account, is the climax of the signs. It leads directly to the decision of the Sanhedrin to kill Jesus. The theme of life predominates. Lazarus is a token of the real life that Jesus dead and raised will give to all who believe in him. Johannine irony is found in the fact that Jesus' gift of life leads to his own death. The story is not found in the synoptics, but cf Mark 5:21 and parallels; Luke 7:11-17. There are also parallels between this story and Luke's parable of the rich man and poor Lazarus ( Luke 16:19-31). In both a man named Lazarus dies; in Luke, there is a request that he return to convince his contemporaries of the need for faith and repentance, while in John, Lazarus does return and some believe but others do not.
annotations.2: [4] Not to end in death: this is misunderstood by the disciples as referring to physical death, but it is meant as spiritual death
annotations.3: [10] The light is not in him: the ancients apparently did not grasp clearly the entry of light through the eye; they seem to have thought of it as being in the eye; cf Luke 11:34; Matthew 6:23
annotations.4: [16] Called Didymus: Didymus is the Greek word for twin. Thomas is derived from the Aramaic word for twin; in an ancient Syriac version and in the Gospel of Thomas (#80: 11-12) his given name, Judas, is supplied
annotations.5: [18] About two miles: literally, "about fifteen stades"; a stade was 607 feet
annotations.6: [27] The titles here are a summary of titles given to Jesus earlier in the gospel
annotations.7: [33] Became perturbed: a startling phrase in Greek, literally, "He snorted in spirit," perhaps in anger at the presence of evil (death)
annotations.8: [41] Father: in Aramaic, abba. See the note on Mark 14:36
annotations.9: [43] Cried out in a loud voice: a dramatization of John 5:28; "the hour is coming when all who are in the tombs will hear his voice."
annotations.10: [48] The Romans will come: Johannine irony; this is precisely what happened after Jesus' death
annotations.11: [49] That year: emphasizes the conjunction of the office and the year. Actually, Caiaphas was high priest A.D. 18-36. The Jews attributed a gift of prophecy, sometimes unconscious, to the high priest
annotations.12: [52] Dispersed children of God: perhaps the "other sheep" of John 10:16
annotations.13: [54] Ephraim is usually located about twelve miles northeast of Jerusalem, where the mountains descend into the Jordan valley
annotations.14: [55] Purify: prescriptions for purity were based on Exodus 19:10-11, 15; Numbers 9:6-14; 2 Chron 30:1-3, 15-18

1.verse: When he had said this, Jesus went out with his disciples across the Kidron valley to where there was a garden, into which he and his disciples entered.

2.verse: Judas his betrayer also knew the place, because Jesus had often met there with his disciples.

3.verse: So Judas got a band of soldiers and guards from the chief priests and the Pharisees and went there with lanterns, torches, and weapons.

4.verse: Jesus, knowing everything that was going to happen to him, went out and said to them, "Whom are you looking for?"

5.verse: They answered him, "Jesus the Nazorean." He said to them, "I AM." Judas his betrayer was also with them.

6.verse: When he said to them, "I AM," they turned away and fell to the ground.

7.verse: So he again asked them, "Whom are you looking for?" They said, "Jesus the Nazorean."

8.verse: Jesus answered, "I told you that I AM. So if you are looking for me, let these men go."

9.verse: This was to fulfill what he had said, "I have not lost any of those you gave me."

10.verse: Then Simon Peter, who had a sword, drew it, struck the high priest's slave, and cut off his right ear. The slave's name was Malchus.

11.verse: Jesus said to Peter, "Put your sword into its scabbard. Shall I not drink the cup that the Father gave me?"

12.verse: So the band of soldiers, the tribune, and the Jewish guards seized Jesus, bound him,

13.verse: and brought him to Annas first. He was the father-in-law of Caiaphas, who was high priest that year.

14.verse: It was Caiaphas who had counseled the Jews that it was better that one man should die rather than the people.

15.verse: Simon Peter and another disciple followed Jesus. Now the other disciple was known to the high priest, and he entered the courtyard of the high priest with Jesus.

16.verse: But Peter stood at the gate outside. So the other disciple, the acquaintance of the high priest, went out and spoke to the gatekeeper and brought Peter in.

17.verse: Then the maid who was the gatekeeper said to Peter, "You are not one of this man's disciples, are you?" He said, "I am not."

18.verse: Now the slaves and the guards were standing around a charcoal fire that they had made, because it was cold, and were warming themselves. Peter was also standing there keeping warm.

19.verse: The high priest questioned Jesus about his disciples and about his doctrine.

20.verse: Jesus answered him, "I have spoken publicly to the world. I have always taught in a synagogue or in the temple area where all the Jews gather, and in secret I have said nothing.

21.verse: Why ask me? Ask those who heard me what I said to them. They know what I said."

22.verse: When he had said this, one of the temple guards standing there struck Jesus and said, "Is this the way you answer the high priest?"

23.verse: Jesus answered him, "If I have spoken wrongly, testify to the wrong; but if I have spoken rightly, why do you strike me?"

24.verse: Then Annas sent him bound to Caiaphas the high priest.

25.verse: Now Simon Peter was standing there keeping warm. And they said to him, "You are not one of his disciples, are you?" He denied it and said, "I am not."

26.verse: One of the slaves of the high priest, a relative of the one whose ear Peter had cut off, said, "Didn't I see you in the garden with him?"

27.verse: Again Peter denied it. And immediately the cock crowed.

28.verse: Then they brought Jesus from Caiaphas to the praetorium. It was morning. And they themselves did not enter the praetorium, in order not to be defiled so that they could eat the Passover.

29.verse: So Pilate came out to them and said, "What charge do you bring (against) this man?"

30.verse: They answered and said to him, "If he were not a criminal, we would not have handed him over to you."

31.verse: At this, Pilate said to them, "Take him yourselves, and judge him according to your law." The Jews answered him, "We do not have the right to execute anyone,"

32.verse: in order that the word of Jesus might be fulfilled that he said indicating the kind of death he would die.

33.verse: So Pilate went back into the praetorium and summoned Jesus and said to him, "Are you the King of the Jews?"

34.verse: Jesus answered, "Do you say this on your own or have others told you about me?"

35.verse: Pilate answered, "I am not a Jew, am I? Your own nation and the chief priests handed you over to me. What have you done?"

36.verse: Jesus answered, "My kingdom does not belong to this world. If my kingdom did belong to this world, my attendants (would) be fighting to keep me from being handed over to the Jews. But as it is, my kingdom is not here."

37.verse: So Pilate said to him, "Then you are a king?" Jesus answered, "You say I am a king. For this I was born and for this I came into the world, to testify to the truth. Everyone who belongs to the truth listens to my voice."

38.verse: Pilate said to him, "What is truth?" When he had said this, he again went out to the Jews and said to them, "I find no guilt in him.

39.verse: But you have a custom that I release one prisoner to you at Passover. Do you want me to release to you the King of the Jews?"

40.verse: They cried out again, "Not this one but Barabbas!" Now Barabbas was a revolutionary.

annotations.1: [1-14] John does not mention the agony in the garden and the kiss of Judas, nor does he identify the place as Gethsemane or the Mount of Olives
annotations.2: [1] Jesus went out: see John 14:31 where it seems he is leaving the supper room. Kidron valley: literally, "the winter-flowing Kidron"; this wadi has water only during the winter rains.
annotations.3: [3] Band of soldiers: seems to refer to Roman troops, either the full cohort of 600 men (1/10 of a legion), or more likely the maniple of 200 under their tribune ( John 18:12). In this case, John is hinting at Roman collusion in the action against Jesus before he was brought to Pilate. The lanterns and torches may be symbolic of the hour of darkness
annotations.4: [5] Nazorean: the form found in Matthew 26:71 (see the note on Matthew 2:23) is here used, not Nazarene of Mark. I AM: or "I am he," but probably intended by the evangelist as an expression of divinity (cf their appropriate response in John 18:6); see the note on John 8:24. John sets the confusion of the arresting party against the background of Jesus' divine majesty
annotations.5: [9] The citation may refer to John 6:39; 10:28; or John 17:12
annotations.6: [10] Only John gives the names of the two antagonists; both John and Luke mention the right ear
annotations.7: [11] The theme of the cup is found in the synoptic account of the agony ( Mark 14:36 and parallels)
annotations.8: [13] Annas: only John mentions an inquiry before Annas; cf John 18:16, 19-24; see the note on Luke 3:2. It is unlikely that this nighttime interrogation before Annas is the same as the trial before Caiaphas placed by Matthew and Mark at night and by Luke in the morning
annotations.9: [15-16] Another disciple . . . the other disciple: see the note on John 13:23
annotations.10: [20] I have always taught . . . in the temple area: cf Mark 14:49 for a similar statement
annotations.11: [24] Caiaphas: see Matthew 26:3, 57; Luke 3:2; and the notes there. John may leave room here for the trial before Caiaphas described in the synoptic gospels
annotations.12: [27] Cockcrow was the third Roman division of the night, lasting from midnight to 3 A.M
annotations.13: [28] Praetorium: see the note on Matthew 27:27. Morning: literally, "the early hour," or fourth Roman division of the night, 3 to 6 A.M. The Passover: the synoptic gospels give the impression that the Thursday night supper was the Passover meal ( Mark 14:12); for John that meal is still to be eaten Friday night
annotations.14: [31] We do not have the right to execute anyone: only John gives this reason for their bringing Jesus to Pilate. Jewish sources are not clear on the competence of the Sanhedrin at this period to sentence and to execute for political crimes
annotations.15: [32] The Jewish punishment for blasphemy was stoning ( Lev 24:16). In coming to the Romans to ensure that Jesus would be crucified, the Jewish authorities fulfilled his prophecy that he would be exalted ( John 3:14; 12:32-33). There is some historical evidence, however, for Jews crucifying Jews
annotations.16: [37] You say I am a king: see Matthew 26:64 for a similar response to the high priest. It is at best a reluctant affirmative
annotations.18: [40] Barabbas: see the note on Matthew 27:16-17. Revolutionary: a guerrilla warrior fighting for nationalistic aims, though the term can also denote a robber. See the note on Matthew 27:38
